results.content: This is the best course in ASP.NET MVC Core 3, which gives comprehensive knowledge and at the same time easy to follow.  The structure of the course is very well planned and covers every aspect of .NET core needed to develop a website to its final deployment. Apart from .NET Core fundamentals, the course also provides good insight into topics like Identity Framework, Razor pages, Sessions, Custom Tag Helpers,  Bootstrap classes, javascript functions, consuming third party packages like Stripe and SendGrid, deploying website on Microsoft Azure, IIS and third party,etc. Overall, this course provides me the complete platform for my future projects in web development.

results.content:
Very down-to-earth step by step instruction. The whole tutorial was split into manageable bite-size and fed to student in a very patient manner, some time feels a little bit slow.

Instructor's way of coding might not exactly be the most efficient way of doing things, but it is guaranteed to work. That's the way I like his courses - he took the time to update and make sure that the content is up-to-date, and if instruction is followed, it will always work. 

Since this is entry-level introduction, instructor skip some pieces and just tell you "this is what you have to do" to make it work. Those looking for further explanation should look beyond this course for answers.

I've already take the course for 2.1, so the coverage of this course feels a little "duplicate". But for fresh student this won't be the case.

I hope to see some further topics, like I18N  and search engine integration with Asp.Net Core. 

Regards

results.content:
Instruction is very good.  Taking this course will accomplish the goal of teaching you to create projects in .Net core that are similar to what you would really do (not "Hello World").    

I only have some small criticisms.  

The sections are very small bite-sizes.  Sometimes that is good, if you are digesting things for the first time.  But a LOT of time is spent saying "in the last video we..." , "in this video we will...." There is a LOT of time spent on transitions because the sections are so short, so there are a LOT of transitions.  I would recommend fewer 4-5 minute sections... lump those together for a 10 minute section.

Secondly - while the instructor does a good job of introducing most subjects, there are times when I'm not sure WHY I am doing something.  For example, using an API call in the Razor page example, some of the Bootstrap classes I've not used before, and some of the front-end scripting... I just copied what was done to make some of these pieces work with only a vague notion of HOW they worked.  I understand they are not the main subjects, but if a few minutes were spent explaining some of those pieces (like was spent explaining entity framework use and some of the linq queries) that would be good.

Oh.. and watch out for one section that was from the previous course / .Net version that explains how to set up the dev environment.... the correct, newer section on the process is present... just after the old one.... that had me scratching my head for a few minutes.

results.content:
Excellent course! If you are looking to learn Dot Net Core development: this is it! 

Just do yourself a favor and follow along part 1 (the Book project) and then at least half of the part 2 (the Spice project) before trying to code a real world app.

Why? Because there are very important concepts in the 2nd part (view models is a good  example) that you need to know before coding something for the real world!

results.content:
It took far too long before there was anything to code.  The first project was interesting as it started with razor pages then added a controller, but there was no comparison of the strengths and weaknesses of Razor Pages versus MVC.
The second project is starting much to simple with a model which only has a single attribute (Category).  There was no need for this to be a model it could have been an enum as it has only a few values.
If it was added as a Model then it should have had a single string field as the primary key with auto key generation off.
In my view the proposed model classes are too simple to be realistic.

results.content:
Great course. Took me about 2.5 months to finish, though I was busy at work and had about zero experience in web-development.
Pros: 
- slow learning curve, you start from making simple razor pages and end with pretty big pages with partial views and view components
- everything is done from scratch
- most times Bhrugen explains theory about .NET core, answers questions
Cons:
- some stuff is already slightly outdated, so be ready to google a little
- it's obvious that he is re-typing code from second screen, so prepare to pause video every 5-10 seconds just to follow
- usage of bootstrap classes is explained rarely; like, he is applying 5+ classes without saying why. I understand that the course is about .NET, but would be nice to have some explanation there too.

All in all, the course is worth every penny. Be sure to know basics of HTML, jQuery, CSS, C# and javascript to get through!

response.content: Thank you so much for the detailed feedback! I will try to explain some topics you mentioned!

results.content:
A wise person once said, "If you want to learn something that is very important for your future, you will make it happen. However, If the energy, passion and commitment are not there, even the best of the strategies won't help you."  

There is always a point in our lives where we need to decide the course of our future strategy, in terms of the bridges that we would like to cross and the ones that we would like to leave behind. In my particular case, the one I decided to cross was the learning of the latest ASP.Net Core technologies using Razor Pages and MVC platforms. And, the one that I decided to abandon was the creation of applications using Web Forms under the .NET Famework whose support from Microsoft appears to be ending in a few more years.

I am not the right person to describe in depth the architecture of the ASP.NET Core, but for one thing I am extremely elated with functionality such as Dependency Injection, Razor Pages, and MVC modeling that makes development of any web, desktop, or mobile application a very robust, simplified and integrated tasks.

So far I have taken several courses on this subject listed on the Udemy Academy, and to my fortune I was able to find Bhrugen Patel, a knowledgeable, competent, and articulate author of several courses related to Razor Pages and ASP.Net Core technologies. 

Bhrugen has developed several courses under Core versions 2.0, 2.1, and 2.2. The last course ASP.Net Core 2.2 is probably his best piece of work with the presentation of real world type of examples that mimic to perfection situations of real life scenarios

results.content:
Overall a good course, covering a lot of topics.

The reason I didn't give 5 starts was because when trying to follow a long typing the code in, sometimes when the provided code caused horizontal scroll bar to appear as such it meant that you had to keep rewinding the video back, which could be avoiding my formatting the code with a few carriage returns, fortunately the master code provided does allow you see what was meant to be inputted.

When switching between code views it was done very quickly so if there was a need to pause to copy what had been done in the lesson you needed lighting fast reactions, so would be nice just to have a 1-2 second pause just to allow a good point for someone to pause the video (or to add a bookmark) and not break the flow of the content.

results.content:
I started as a database architect and through necessity began with a couple of small full stack projects.  What makes Bhrugen's courses stand out is that I have a strong background and am usually just looking for a few "what am I missing here" odds and ends, but I can actually watch this without losing interest.  At the same time, if you had very little exposure, you would pick up concepts and be comfortable with the process by the time you were done with the course, but it isn't going to be over your head.  

I was in a pinch and needed a couple of specifics for ASP.NET core 2.2 so without hesitation I went back to Bhrugen.  The course is divided in a way that whether you are a new developer wanting to see the parts work, you're discovering frameworks for the first time or you're just looking for some "what's new in 2.2?" its well worth the investment.  I use Bhrugen's course when I'm looking for something specific, but every time I have a friend asking me for a good overview, he presents it well and is very quick to answer so I recommend it to people any time I'm asked.

results.content:
Instructor successfully delivers content and in reasonable order and at reasonable level of granularity.

It would be nice if the instructor would leave the solution explorer visible so students could see what file he just opened, etc. (The content progresses so fast that as I move my eyes from the video to my working Visual Studio code, I totally loose where the instructor was just clicking to open a file. That is kind of distracting and does a dis-service to the student who tries to follow along.)

Also, it would be nice to have the instructor provide an updated codebase every so often, just in case the student is not able to figure out where he/she went wrong (it may have been several videos ago).

The Intro is fine to follow along, coding (Book Project) is somewhat fast for the first watch, i have basic html, css knowledge, but i need to get a familiar with bootstrap since its used frequently .  I ve basic knowledge of C# and  i see its not enough to work comfortably with IEnums and interfaces and so on.  
My suggestion is to make an extra curses for the following topics : 1- working with json files 2-  essential OOP concepts like inheritance, interfaces ... etc.  3- basic bootstrap .  I personal would like to have a mush up of essential tools and concepts wrapped together specifically as preparation for this course .  Another question/tip , a course that tackles the analysis of a problem that goes in parallel with coding, i mean making relational diagrams and UML, i think it would be great to have a bundle of 2 or more courses that advance in parallel. the first is to collect requirements and draw the sachems,  the other is to implement that in code.
